item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Post One
item.dc:creator: Jakeclements
item.content:encoded:
[reagallery name="Gallery change"] 'You can't think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!' said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice's, and they walked off together.
Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so savage when they met in the kitchen.
'When I'M a Duchess,' she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though), 'I won't have any pepper in my kitchen AT ALL. Soup does very well withoutMaybe it's always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,' she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule, 'and vinegar that makes them sourand camomile that makes them bitterandand barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn't be so stingy about it, you know' Gallery Example: [reagallery name="Gallery Example"] 'You can't think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!' said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice's, and they walked off together. Tag Two as a test.

item.title: 6 tips for creating a relaxing outdoor living space
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley

item.title: A household history of the fridge
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever experienced a black out and felt completely helpless without the use of a fridge? No milk to have in your tea. No cheese for your sandwich. Warm soft drinks. This happened to me just a week ago and after I had got over the fact that I couldnt have my usual yogurt for breakfast, I got thinking about how humans lived before the invention of the fridge. How summer made food consumption a veritable land-mine of disease and potentially fatal illness and how poverty could prevent the average family from being able to afford ice. I also got thinking about the different fridges I've had in my life. The boxy brown linoleum number my parents bought in the 1970s. The white 1980s brick we had when I was a child with the tightest vacuum seal I've ever come across. The sleek silver beast I have in my kitchen now, with the little compartments for eggs. Here's a brief history of our beloved refrigeratorand the various makeovers it's had since it's arrival on our domestic scene in 1927.  

1927

The first ever fridge made by General Electric was called a 'Monitor-Top'. To purchase this in 1927, it would have set you back around $520. Fridges looked very similar to this right up until the late 1940s.  

1950s

Fridges in the 1950s got a lot fancier. They were aimed at the middle classes or 'slave-free households'. Marketed towards housewives, they were supposed to be a point of pride for the woman of the house, and it was a popular look for the fridge to match the walls and cupboards of the kitchen.  

1960s

Fridges in the 1960s reflected the look of the time. Futuristic, yet simple and with soft curves in the design. By the 1960s most fridges also included a freezer compartment for mum to stock up on family dinners. There was a subtle touch of The Jetsons about fridges in this era, hinting at a tantalising future of efficiency and domestic freedom. Perhaps even robot chefs!

1970s

The 1970s saw a rise in the popularity of miniature and novelty fridges. The design of the household fridge also took a turn back towards the more boxy look of the 1940s. Compact was back.

1980s

Fridges of the 1980s were sturdy, utilitarian and built to last. A good portion of Australian homes have a garage fridge that looks very similar to the one pictured above. Maybe you still do. Here's applicance makers Fisher and Paykel ushering in a new decade of fridge fashion.  

1990s

The 1990s saw the introduction of stainless steel to our fridge facades. Sleek and modern was in, as was the French-door style, with a double door and a bottom freezer. Fridges were glam and contemporary, with the old white clunkers gradually falling out of favour through the decade. With climate change and electricity costs getting more attention, the Energy Star system became a mainstay.

2000

The noughties saw the arrival of the in-fridge ice maker, water dispenser and 'handy grab' doors for quick access to drinks storage. Fridges also starting converging with other technology, and in 2000 LG launched the first internet enabled fridge. Sadly, the net fridge wasn't a hit, with consumers deciding that it wasn't everything they needed after all. These days, iPads and other mobile devices let us have those receipes close to hand, and when we run out of milk, we can always grab an app to take care of it, rather than rely on the fridge itself.

6 interesting facts about fridges

 
  • Electrolux was the first company to patent the domestic refrigerator in 1922.
  • In America in the early 1920s a domestic fridge cost on average $600, which is equivalent to $7000 in today's currency. By the time production reached Australia several years later the latest model was fetching around $200.
  • By 1964 it's estimated that 94% of Australian homes had a fridge.
  • The method used to artificially manufacture ice was invented in Australia in 1851 by a man called James Harrison using an ether compression machine. The shipping of snow and ice was expensive because Australia is so large and warm and his method made ice more affordable for the average Aussie family.
  • From the late 1800s until 1929 fridges used toxic gases ammonia, methyl chloride and sulfur dioxide as refrigerants. Several people died from fatal toxic gas leaks during this time.
  • Sir Francis Bacon was one of the first people to figure out that cold could be used to preserve meat. He started experimenting with the refrigeration of food in 1626. He developed pneumonia as a result of his experiments and died a few months later.
Next time you're reaching for your drink at the back of the fridge, take a moment to think how grand life is thanks to this ingenious invention. Perhaps also spare a thought for Sir Bacon. He did have rather an appropriate name for the job though.   15/4/13

item.title: Photography the top tool for real estate agents
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded:
It's something most of us know instinctively, whether we've been browsing for homes, proudly showing off our own for sale, or just admiring and dreaming. Good looking images, that show off a home at its best, entice us to look closer. One responsent commented: "Professional photography is 100% essential to marketing any home, at any price range in any location. I will not put a home on the market without the highest quality photography. It attracts more buyers and therefore a higher sale price for our owners." Another highlighted that great images are synonymouswith professional property sales: "Good photography can be the difference between a purchaser opening a web link or moving on to the next. Additionally, the way an office markets property directly reflects their professionalism to the public." Agents said beautiful photography:
  • attracts more buyers (89%)
  • increases enquiries (79%)
  • increased clicks to their online listings (68%)
  • secure a higher selling price (52%)
"The survey results demonstrate how almost every agent now recognises the importance of professional photography, along with a range of other tools, in successfully marketing their listings," said Top Snap's General Manager, Helen Clarke. Other marketing tools agents consider important are floor plans (84%), site plans (67%), copywriting (65%), virtual tours (63%), virtual furniture (56%) andproperty video (21%). 27/9/12 Got a story you think our community should hear? Emaileditor@realestate.com.au

item.title: Lenders costing home owners by ignoring rates
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded:
Despite the Reserve Bank dropping the cash rate six times since November 2011 (totaling 175 basis points) standard variable home loan rates fell by 133 basis points on average, based on RateCitys database of more than 100 lenders around Australia. This 42 basis points translates to around $80 in monthly repayments for a $300,000 home loan according to RateCity. "Even though variable home loans have been falling for more than a year, which has saved borrowers $264 in monthly repayments for a $300,000 mortgage, many borrowers missed out on further savings because most lenders didnt pass on rate cuts in full," she said. RateCity says the gap between official interest rates and lender offerings should be a 'wake up call' for borrowers and buyers alike to not become complacent about their loan situation or the options available. Keeping track of the performance of your home loan and how it fares against the rest of the market isn't an indulgence, it's a necessity, especially as bankd and other lenders increasingly move indepedently of Reserve Bank decisions. Hutchinson said she anticipates more "out-of-cycle" rate movements during 2013. "While further relief may be in sight, borrowers need to concentrate on the actual rate they are paying. Keep track of your home loan, compare it online to the rest of the market and re-negotiate or switch to a better deal," she cautioned.   8/1/13 Related reading
  • ANZ joins rivals to offer partial rate cut
  • Big banks cut a fraction
  • How comparison sites can get you a better deal
  Got a story you think our community should hear? Emaileditor@realestate.com.au

item.title: No nonsense guide to moving in a hurry
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded:
If you find yourself in need of moving house in an honest-to-goodness rush, there's some things that you will absolutely need to do before you move. Then there's some things you may think you need to do, but they can be done from the comfort of your new home (once they get around to reconnecting your internet...)  

Things to do right away, before panic sets in

Call two moving companies, get quotes, and ensure availability on your moving day. If they are not available, keep on calling until you find one that is. Organise your packing materials. You can rent boxes for the duration of your move, and while you're at it get some portable wardrobes for your delicate items. Save more time and have packing paper and bubble wrap delivered at the same time. You may be able to get free boxes from shops or friends, but if time is a premium, it's usually easier to organise them through a provider. Call the utility companies to organise transferring your services. Some utilities take up to seven business days to complete a transfer, so if you wait until moving day to inform them, you might end up paying for the new tenant's electricity, of be without communications in your new home for a long time. List items online that you intend to sell. Most listings last for seven days, but you also have to leave time for the person to come and pick up the item, which can take a few days to coordinate. Re-direct your mail. You can change your address with banks, and government agencies later, but in the short term, the post office will redirect your mail for one, three, six months or a year. Mail redirection also takes a few days to start, so talk to the the post officeearly.

Things to do as D-day approaches

  • Pack a personal survival kit: separate out essential items that youll need in the inevitable two or three days of insanity over your move. Toiletries, coffee, milk, bread and snacks, medicine, a few clothes, some tea-towels, toilet paper, and some paper towels.
  • Pack a moving kit: moving day will require multi-tasking with administrative issues, and getting your hands dirty with some last minute repairs so make sure to pack a bag or box with: both leases (new and old), a utility knife, a multi-screwdriver, hammer, wrench, tape measure, a notebook and a pen.You'll also want any critical gadgets and devices (like phones and tablets) fully charged.
  • The day before your move: pack everything up, label your boxes clearly with the destination room, the contents are less critical since the removalists only need to know where to drop the boxes.

On moving day

In your old home:

  • Be on hand to direct the removalists
  • Disassemble large items table, trampoline, entertainment centre
  • Don't get underfoot the removalists move fast!
  • Check over your old home for left items

In your new home:

  • Be on hand to answer questions and to supervise unloading and unpacking
  • Check for damage to your items, and make sure to indicate it to the chief removalist before signing or paying the invoice
  • Check over the new house for damage and stains on the carpet, and note it on the condition report
  • Complete the condition report
In truth, a move is a couple of really tough days (and a couple of weeks of dust settling). If you ignore the trivial items, and focus on the critical ones, you'll make it through.

item.title: New building designs needed: expert
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded: Addressing a forum of NSW government planners on Thursday, Dr Karen Lee described building designs and active transport options that could increase physical activity and access to healthier food in Sydney. Only half of the NSW population gets the recommended 30 minutes of daily exercise, the forum heard, while 52.5% adults are overweight and children's rates are fast catching up. Dr Lee, an award-winning healthy urban planning expert, said the city could alleviate this problem by designing better buildings and "pedestrian realms". "One of the things that's worked really well in New York and Chicago is they've created something called `play streets', which are single blocks of quieter streets that are closed off to cars at certain times so children and their families can come out and play," Dr Lee told AAP. She said schools could also apply for the permits for play streets, if they don't have enough space for physical education. Dr Lee said the plan could particularly help Sydney as space shortages continue and schools go high-rise. "Green roofs" are also another option the city could consider, Dr Lee said. "They're good for the environment and decreasing heat generation from concrete buildings. They're also great places for children and adults to play or be active." Dr Lee said governments should look at tax incentives for supermarkets and grocers to set up in high-density areas. "It reduces the need for people to get in the car and drive to the supermarket. It also means people have access to healthy food in areas which are `food deserts'," she said. The NSW Department of Planning and Infrastructure said active and open spaces are one of its key plans to help reduce Australia's obesity rates. Image: Garden in subway car, Chicago/Inhabitat 8/2/13

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start blogging!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To delete a comment, just log in and view the post's comments. There you will have the option to edit or delete them.

item.title: Post belongs to RE Category
item.dc:creator: Jakeclements
item.content:encoded:
Not having a lease

This is a legally enforceable contract which usually spells out the length of the rental agreement, the amount of rent that will be paid, and the condition the property must be returned in.

Failing to fill out condition report

This document describes the standard of repair for the premises and any items included within the premises, such as furniture. It is designed to protect the interests of both parties.

Unclear understanding of the tenancy laws

Property management can be very complex and if landlords don't comply with the legislation it can lead to fines. There are different Acts legislating tenancies in each state.

item.title: 5 Reasons a pre-purchase building inspection is essential
item.dc:creator: Jakeclements
item.content:encoded: Minister McArdle says 92,000 households of the 190,000 that have solar panels are not paying a dime for their electricity. "I don't believe that was the intent of the scheme and the debate must be had on who should pay what, in regards of their power bills, when you consider a large number of people pay no power bill at all," he said. There'll be no change to the solar scheme in Tuesday's budget, however a review of the Electricity Act could result in changes. "Solar is on the agenda," he said. "We need to debate the issue of solar and how we get an equitable outcome going forward." Residents with solar power are paid 44 cents a kilowatt hour for electricity they put back into the grid, about 21 cents a kilowatt hour more than what it costs them to produce. Mr McArdle says it added $67 to power bills in 2012-13 and is forecast to skyrocket to $276 by 2015-16. He says another $180 could be wiped off bills if the federal government "eradicated" the carbon tax and other green policies. "The federal issues could happen within a twinkling of an eye, it's that quick, it's simply getting rid of them and getting immediate relief," he said. The independent Queensland Competition Authority announced on Friday households would pay 22.6 per cent more from July and small business 17.4 per cent. Overall, maintenance of the network's poles and wires, deferred network costs and solar subsidies, account for about half of the power hike. Cabinet is debating on Monday how it can lower revenue raised by the state-owned electricity distributors, a price set by the Australian Energy Regulator. Opposition Leader Annastacia Palaszczuk said the premier knew the figures before last year's election but kept mum. "He wants to change the goal posts - if they want to change the scheme, they need to be upfront and tell people why." She said the argument that 92,000 people weren't paying for their electricity wasn't fair, as they had outlaid huge costs for the solar panels.

item.title: Affordable housing remains a concern: govt
item.dc:creator: heather-connell
item.content:encoded:
Housing affordability remains a concern for many Australian families, Housing and Homelessness Minister Mark Butler says.

The minister on Thursday met with a group of Adelaide tenants benefiting from affordable home rentals under a government-backed scheme. New incentives under the scheme will provide for an extra 1000 homes to be built across Australia by June next year. "We want to move as quickly as possible to build new homes in areas that are most in need and to give the business and community sector more certainty for the future," Mr Butler said. "This scheme is a critical part of the Australian government's efforts to help Australians struggling in the housing market. "We remain firmly committed to delivering 50,000 more affordable rental homes by June 2016." The National Rental Affordability Scheme offers incentives of almost $10,000 every year for ten years to people who build and rent out new homes or apartments to low-income tenants.
item.excerpt:encoded: Housing affordability remains a concern for many Australian families, Housing and Homelessness Minister Mark Butler says.

item.title: 6 reasons to think about building versus renovating
item.dc:creator: heather-connell
item.content:encoded:
If the latest series of 'The Block' was anything to go by, Aussies haven't lost their passion for renovating, with over two million people tuning in for the show's grand finale. While it's very entertaining to watch others sink their blood, sweat and tears into a renovation, it's not always as much fun doing it yourself. And it's also not necessarily the smartest way to go!   Knocking down and rebuilding can be a more cost effective option than renovating an old home. Here are my top six things to consider for renovating versus building new:

Weigh up the costs

If you're planning an extensive renovation with a lot of structural changes, it can definitely be cheaper to start from scratch. As a general guide, you can build a brand new single-storey home from around $200,000 and a two-storey design from around $250,000. Keep in mind renovation costs also can blow out, due to unforseen problems that arise along the way. One of the upsides of building a new home is you can ask your builder for a fixed price contract. [caption id="attachment_219" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Image: Ausbuild[/caption]

Consider the age of the home

If you've purchased a character home because you love the old timber floors and decorative ceilings, renovation will obviously be the best way to go, even if it is more cost. Rebuilding is not an option if your home has period features. The most suitable knockdowns are the ugly ducklings that can often be purchased for close to land value.

Location is a factor

Knocking down and rebuilding is more popular in locations where vacant land is scarce and also in sought after areas close to the city, beach or bay, where there is little risk of over capitalising. If you're unsure whether it's a good idea for your suburb, get some advice from a local real estate agent. It's also essential to find out from your local council what you can and can't do under local planning laws. [caption id="attachment_223" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Image: Ausbuild[/caption]

Consider your lifestyle

Rather than trying to fix an unworkable floor plan by extending or raising an existing house, it can be easier and cheaper to start with a clean slate. Rebuilding allows people to choose a new home design to suit their needs, rather than trying to modernise an older home.

Budget for ongoing expenses

New homes are easier to maintain, less susceptible to termites and more energy efficient. Building practices and regulations are also much better now and a new home comes with the added peace of mind of a warranty on the construction. [caption id="attachment_220" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Image: Ausbuild[/caption]

Do want the hassle of renovating?

If you work full-time or are raising a family, you need to ask yourself whether you really want to spend every weekend working on the house. Renovating can be very disruptive, often requiring the homeowners to move out for a period of time. On the other hand, new homes can be built to 'turn key' stage, where all you need to do is turn the key, walk in and enjoy. Deciding on whether to renovate or rebuild is a big decision and an expensive one. Whichever way you go, it's vital to do your homework first.
item.excerpt:encoded: If the latest series of 'The Block' was anything to go by, Aussies haven't lost their passion for renovating, with over two million people tuning in for the show's grand finale. While it's very entertaining to watch others sink their blood, sweat and tears into a renovation, it's not always as much fun doing it yourself. And it's also not necessarily the smartest way to go!

item.title: Low income renters 'priced out of Sydney'
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded:
The national charity examined more than 11,000 rental ads in the greater Sydney and Illawarra regions, and uncovered a tale of two cities for low-income households.
For single parents, the disabled, the elderly, full-time students, and the unemployed, finding an affordable and appropriate rental dwelling which costs less than a third of their household income is an impossible challenge, the report showed.
"Anglicare is concerned that low-income households are becoming increasingly marginalised and excluded from opportunities for a better and more secure future," said Sydney CEO Grant Millard.
Only 73 properties of those listed in the region, met the criteria for affordability and appropriateness.
Only one rental property was located within 20km of the Sydney CBD, with the vast majority of remaining properties confined to areas two to three hours further afield.
Even then, many residents would need to rely heavily on private transport in the absence of public transport to access services, amenities, and employment opportunities.
Anglicare's Sydney CEO Grant Millard said governments at all levels need to have a serious look at how they will boost appropriate and affordable housing.
He said he doesn't want to see low-income families pushed to the outskirts.
"We want to see people integrated into the community: when you think of public housing you think of the worst examples, and we want to avoid any aspects of ghettoisation and low-income families being segregated and preyed upon," Mr Millard told AAP.
"Currently the sort of investment that occurs is not on public transport routes, and that's a problem - if you want people to be job-ready they need to be able to live near public transport hubs."
More than one third of households privately renting who access Anglicare's Emergency Relief are in severe rental stress, spending more than 45% of their income in rent.
"We're aware that the federal government has recently announced a new round of funding to support 1,000 new homes under the National Rental Affordability Scheme," Mr Millard said.
"However, with a current housing shortfall of about 89,000 dwellings in NSW, far more needs to be done in this area."
He said the NSW government should include clear, affordable social housing targets in their metropolitan strategy for Sydney 2031, and ensure local councils require new developments near public transport to include social and public housing.

item.title: First home buyers rush to benefit budget changes
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded:
The Victorian Coalition Government has announced substantial changes to first home buyer grants and the fast-tracking of changes to stamp duty, which is altering buyer behavior in this first home market. The proposed changes include the deletion of grants to first home buyers looking to buy an established property and an increase to grants for new builds.

So what's changed?

From 1 July 2013, the First Home Owner Grant (FHOG) will increase from $7,000 to $10,000 for newly constructed houses and apartments, including those built under a home building contract, built by an owner-builder, purchased off the plan or sold for the first time as a residential premise. In addition, the Coalition Government is bringing forward stamp duty cuts of 40% for all first home owners. The impact of this announcement has hit home with many first home buyers who are looking to take advantage of the current grants as well as future changes. Since the announcement, realestate.com.au has experienced an increase in buyer inquiry for Victorian properties, in price brackets popular with first home owners. Also, the building industry has indicated interest in new home options has heightened. Treasurer Michael OBrien says the combination of a $10,000 FHOG and 40% stamp duty cut means that Victorians buying a newly constructed first home for $400,000 will save over $16,500. However, the downside of this announcement means that the first home owners wanting to purchase an existing dwelling only have until 1 July to benefit from existing grants. This is what potentially has lead to the increase of buyer activity on realestate.com.au in the traditional first home buyer brackets (up to $300,000). Mr O'Brien says increasing the FHOG on newly constructed properties and boosting the stamp duty concession will make the dreams of many young Victorians become a reality sooner. "The Coalition Government wants to support Victorians who are saving to buy their first home," he says. These changes also bring Victoria in line with New South Wales, Queensland and South Australia.  

Renewed interest in new homes

  Metricon's CEO Mario Biasin says the Victorian Government announcement is welcome news for aspiring buyers. "Certainly new home buyer confidence has waned over the past 18 months so the increased grant and fast tracked stamp duty saving will provide a helpful boost to morale in this market. "This boost coupled with continuing low interest rates should encourage people to go out shopping for their first home and really consider building a new home versus the higher cost of renting," says Mr Biasin. He says Metricon has already seen an increase in first home buyer enquiry. "We are working hard to keep our home prices competitive, offering home and land packages and finance options to make home ownership easy and affordable." For example, Mr Biasin says, you can buy a new Metricon home with three bedrooms in Wollert for as little as $400* per week (approx), which is about the same or less than some people are currently paying in rent. "Metricon's goal is to make home ownership more accessible for thousands of new home buyers, many of whom have found it difficult in the past to purchase," says Mr Biasin. Another advantage to first home buyers is the next September 2014 50 per cent stamp duty concession for all first home buyers (whether purchasing newly constructed or established homes).   Contract Date (1 July 2013 onwards) - Subject to the passage of legislation   * Home and Land Package at $400 per week based on: Lot 408 Raychelsbury Parade Eden Gardens Estate, Wollert Block Size: 378m NOVA 17 Traditional $368,656* Bank West Interest rate of 5.59% over 30 years

item.title: Low income renters 'priced out of Sydney'
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded:
The national charity examined more than 11,000 rental ads in the greater Sydney and Illawarra regions, and uncovered a tale of two cities for low-income households.
For single parents, the disabled, the elderly, full-time students, and the unemployed, finding an affordable and appropriate rental dwelling which costs less than a third of their household income is an impossible challenge, the report showed.
"Anglicare is concerned that low-income households are becoming increasingly marginalised and excluded from opportunities for a better and more secure future," said Sydney CEO Grant Millard.
Only 73 properties of those listed in the region, met the criteria for affordability and appropriateness.
Only one rental property was located within 20km of the Sydney CBD, with the vast majority of remaining properties confined to areas two to three hours further afield.
Even then, many residents would need to rely heavily on private transport in the absence of public transport to access services, amenities, and employment opportunities.
Anglicare's Sydney CEO Grant Millard said governments at all levels need to have a serious look at how they will boost appropriate and affordable housing.
He said he doesn't want to see low-income families pushed to the outskirts.
"We want to see people integrated into the community: when you think of public housing you think of the worst examples, and we want to avoid any aspects of ghettoisation and low-income families being segregated and preyed upon," Mr Millard told AAP.
"Currently the sort of investment that occurs is not on public transport routes, and that's a problem - if you want people to be job-ready they need to be able to live near public transport hubs."
More than one third of households privately renting who access Anglicare's Emergency Relief are in severe rental stress, spending more than 45% of their income in rent.
"We're aware that the federal government has recently announced a new round of funding to support 1,000 new homes under the National Rental Affordability Scheme," Mr Millard said.
"However, with a current housing shortfall of about 89,000 dwellings in NSW, far more needs to be done in this area."
He said the NSW government should include clear, affordable social housing targets in their metropolitan strategy for Sydney 2031, and ensure local councils require new developments near public transport to include social and public housing.
 
29/4/13

item.title: A first timer's guide to moving out on your own
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded:
Here are some tips to help you fly out of the nest and not flee back again just as fast.  

Consider your decision to move

There are many reasons to move out maybe it's your decision, maybe it is someone elses, maybe it is necessity, maybe it is just time. No matter why you're moving on think about it calmly. Are you ready to live independently? What are your options? And if it is your decision, are you moving out for the right reasons? Dont make a rash decision that could see you needing to move back home again soon, and make sure you consider all the avenues available to you.  

Find the right place

Whether you're buying, sharing or renting, you'll need to work out what kind of property best suits you and your lifestyle. Ask yourself some serious questions. Can you live alone or is a flat share the best option? Will you be happy in a grungy share house or is a slick inner city pad more your style? What can you actually afford? And where? If you're testing the waters maybe a room in a share house rather than taking the lease in your own name is best to start with. Start your search online, but dont stop there: you cant tell everything from photos, so make sure you attend several open houses to get a sense of what your budget really buys you. And if you're looking for someone to live with, check out our tips for finding the perfect flatmate.

Finances

Leaving home is expensive, and it doesn't take long for bad budgeting to lead to financial hardship, so you need to plan ahead. A recent study found some young Australians were going without food and borrowing money to survive when they moved out of home. Avoid this situation by calculating your known monthly income then planning a monthly budget for food, bills, transport, entertainment and extras. Always pay any bills and rent on time to avoid a bad credit rating. If you want to buy a home later on, someone will be looking at how you managed financially. Dont forget that when setting up or moving house there are also establishment fees such as a rental bond (usually a month's rent in advance), phone, cable TV, gas, electricity or internet connection fees, as well as the set up costs of furnishing rooms or equipping a kitchen. It's also smart to take out home contents insurance, just in case. No matter how much, or how little money you have, managing your money well is the best foundation to living independently and this will have flow on effects to all aspects of your life.

Chores

Moving out gives you independence, freedom and adventure, but it all comes with added responsibilities. Without sounding like mum and dad, try to keep on top of the chores like cleaning, cooking, laundry, and taking the bins out. You don't want to fall into the clich of being a typical first time out of home slob! Look after yourself: if you're used to having meals cooked for you at home make sure you get into a rhythm of cooking yourself, rather than s kipping meals or relying on take away every night (that'll eat into your budget too).

Communicate

Communication is the key to any relationship and it is no different for your flatmates or partner (assuming you are not living alone). Avoid conflict by setting ground rules, being open and respecting others' opinions (including any opinions they have on the way you live. Living independently for the first time you'll face your share of surprises, including the challenges of living with others. It's common for this to make people a bit nervous or unsettled. Remember you're not alone, and work on expressing how you're feeling to avoid misunderstandings.

Hide a spare key

  There's nothing worse than the surprise of an after-hours call out fee for a locksmith, so give someone you trust a spare key to your house. (No, don't hide it in the garden).

Keep in touch

No matter how old you are, if it's your first time out of home your parents or guardians will probably miss you. Give them a call from time to time or go home for a meal! Just try not to land on the doorstep with the washing too often.

Practice

If you're thinking about moving out, see if you can trial it for a while to test your skills at budgeting and housework. Perhaps you could stay with a friend. Or get a short term rental for a few months. Another idea is to get your parents to let you 'run the house' for a month or two, and be responsible for as much as you practically can. This will give you a better idea of what's involved, and may give them a chance to put their feet up. If you don't do your own washing, now's the time to start. Make sure you can do all the things you'll need to do when you step out.

Ask for help

Moving out for the first time can be daunting, and theres a lot to get on top of. Don't be too proud to ask for help if you find yourself under financial or emotional stress or if you have any other kind of trouble. While your parents might be there for you, not everyone who moves out can move back home or ask their parents for help in times of trouble so make sure youre familiar with the community or government organisations that can lend a hand. These vary depending on which location you're in, but include:
  • Kids Helpline Tel. 1800 551 800
  • Lifeline 13 11 44
  • Home Ground Services 1800 048 325
  • Relationships Australia Tel. 1300 364 277
  • Centrelink Crisis or Special Help Tel. 13 28 50
If you need to move out but can't afford a place of your own you can contact your local housing authority to see if there's any financial assistance they can offer:
  • ACT-Housing and Community Services13 34 27
  • NSW-Housing NSW1300 468 746
  • Northern Territory-Territory Housing
  • Queensland-Housing and Homelessness Services1300 880 882
  • South Australia-Department for Communities and Social Inclusion (DCSI)08-8226 8800
  • Tasmania-Housing Tasmania(Department of Health and Human Services 1300 135 513; TTY users phone 133 677 then ask for 1300 13 55 13)
  • Victoria-Office of Housing1300 650 172
  • Western Australia-Department of Housing1800 093 325
Don't leave it too late to seek professional advice if you feel things getting on top of you.

Did you know?

Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that in 2006, almost one in four people aged 2034 years were living at home with their parents, compared with 19% in 1986. The proportion of young women living at home had increased from 13% to 18%, and young men were more likely than young women to live with their parents. By age 28 around 94% of people had moved out of home (at least for a while) and by 34 that figure was close to 97%. It pays to be realistic though: the chance of returning to mum and dad at least once before turning 35 is almost one in two (46%), with most returners lasting only one to two years out of home before going back.

item.title: Despite incentives, we're reluctant to build
item.dc:creator: Jakeclements
item.content:encoded:
The Australian Industry Group/Housing Industry Association Australian Performance of Construction Index has been releasaaaaaaaed, and it shows a still struggling construction sector continuing on a bumpy road. Nationally our building industry finished 2012 in negative territory, after a year of declining activity. However December results showed a slight drop off in that decline, especially for commercial construction. Buthouse building and apartment building is still ailing.A reduction is home buyer enquiries and a lack of commitment from potential buyers was cited as affecting our desire to raise the roof. An index below 50 indicates a contraction in the industry. December came in at 38.8 overall. New orders were up 8.3 points on November to 42.6, andconstruction activity was up 3.8 pointsto 39.6. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="356"] Despite incentives, we're reluctant to build[/caption] Australian Industry Group Director Public Policy, Peter Burn said there were some modest signs of improvement. "For the industry as a whole, new orders declined at a distinctly slower rate in December.In particular, commercial construction activity levels appear likely to stabilise as private investment in key marketsshows early signs of improving. New orders in commercial construction recorded their first expansion sinceOctober 2010 while intakes of new business also improved in the engineering and apartment sectors." However our lack of enthusiam for building new homes is a concern, especially in light of 2012 government grant changes across the states designed to incentivise building anew versus buying established. Consumer confidence is considered a strong factor, with Australians seemingly still too nervous to take a long term plunge.
"While a third consecutive slowing in the overallpace of contraction in the Australian PCI marks an encouraging end to 2012, the updates for housing weredisappointing," saidHousing Industry Association Chief Economist, Harley Dale.
"Detached house building represents well over 60% of all residential construction activity inAustralia and the December 2012 Australian PCI points to a steeper decline in activity and new orders, not tomention employment. "All up, if policy makers were hoping thefirst housing update out in 2013 would deliver a signal of current policy settings boosting the chance of a new homebuilding recovery, theyre going to have to keep hoping,"said Dale. You can read the full report online here. The Australian Industry Group/Housing Industry Association Australian Performance of Construction Index (Australian PCI) is aseasonally adjusted national composite index based on the diffusion indexes for activity, orders/new business, deliveries and employment. 9/1/13

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: With kitchens a focus of the modern home, the pressure is on to make the most of yours, even if it doesn't fit the most popular mould. Here's some tips to get the most out of the least.

item.title: Tips for heading back to school after a move
item.dc:creator: Lucy Birchley
item.content:encoded:
Other than sticking to your existing routines (always a good way to help family members adapt into strange surrounds), there's some terrific services and communities out there that can help you ease into the new school year with less stress - especially if you're new in the area.

MamaBake

www.mamabake.com From the first time I heard of MamaBake I loved it! A big batch, cooking group for mums, it helps ease the burden of having to think what to cook every night, as well as saves you time by sharing the cooking with other like-minded mums. Here's the Basic MamaBake Formula: 1. Mamas gather for approximately three hours per week (or as frequently as your group decides) to cook up a big-batch meal. 2. At the end of the session, each big-batch meal gets divided up amongst the mamas so that each woman goes home with a variety of homecooked meals for a few nights. Simple! You can join the MamaBake Movement here it started in Australia, but now there are groups popping up all around the world. With over 200 groups across Australia there may already be one in your area or you start your own. Sign up and youll get the MamaBake ebook with a poster for you to print out and use to recruit new members and a couple of big batch recipes to get you started.

FindaUniform

www.findauniform.com.au FindAUniform, a national online second hand uniform noticeboard, was started by a good friend of mine. Bernadettes family frequently moves for work (moving with kids across three states in seven years!) and she was sick of being frustrated by how difficult it was to find an easy to use, national second hand uniform website for school, dance, nippers, soccer and all the other activities her four daughters do. She started FindAUniform for busy parents, particularly those grappling with a move. The site lets you buy, sell and swap uniforms, and place wanted ads. Clear out the old stuff, get the new stuff for the new school. Not only is buying and selling second hand uniforms good for your pocket, you can also feel good about helping the environment by reducing landfill. Double bonus!

Carpooling

Does your school suffer from that long snake of cars that slowly roll towards the official drop off area each morning, with each car unloading just one, maybe two kids. How about sharing the drop off and pick up with families near you? Or better yet, if you live near your school,setting up a Walking Bus. The busis a fantastic way to inject more exercise into your week and get to know the families near you. An ideal exercise to help you settle in to a new neighbourhood, and get the family where they need to be with less hassle. Have a happy and healthy 2013!   4/2/13
